awd_titl_txt: Elucidating the Mechanisms of Irradiation Induced Softening in Nanocrystalline BCC Metals
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: 
Coupled extremes of high stresses and irradiation necessitate new materials design methodologies for enhancing strength and radiation tolerance through precise control over material structure. Over the past two decades, nanocrystalline metals that contain a large fraction of internal interfaces have been pursued to address the performance limitations of traditional engineering alloys. These unique materials exhibit significant improvements in mechanical properties such as strength and wear resistance, but under certain irradiation conditions, develop internal defects that degrade these properties and limit their technological utility for extreme environment applications. Using an integrated computational and experimental framework, this research will build a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms responsible for such property degradations, specifically characterizing the intricate defect networks that produce softening and hardening in nanocrystalline metals under irradiation. Technologically, new insights into the impact of irradiation on the mechanical performance of nanocrystalline metals will foster innovations in materials design for extreme environments to advance next-generation nuclear technologies as safe, sustainable energy sources with drastically reduced environmental impacts. The integration of research activities into educational initiatives will advance the engagement of underrepresented students in materials science and provide curriculum enrichment for engineering majors through the establishment of a new materials science and engineering major at Stony Brook University.    

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: 
This research will elucidate the mechanisms responsible for the transition from softening to hardening in nanocrystalline body centered cubic (BCC) metals containing helium irradiation defects. The guiding hypothesis is nanoscale helium defects aggregated in grain boundaries act as stress concentrations that reduce the energetic barrier for grain boundary mediated dislocation nucleation, which in turn manifests as a softening effect that ultimately competes with classical irradiation hardening. The research team will combine atomistic simulations with in situ mechanical testing experiments and nanoindentation to explore the influence of helium irradiation defects on the fundamental deformation processes in the nanocrystalline BCC metals tungsten and iron. The competition between classical irradiation hardening found in coarse-grained polycrystalline metals and softening prevalent in nanocrystalline materials will also be explored by considering the coupling of intragranular defect loop damage with grain boundary defects in the deformation behavior. The manifestation of these mechanisms in the mechanical response will be quantified and used to build mechanism-property maps on the basis of collective interactions of deformation mechanisms with irradiation defects. From this research, the team will gain a new understanding of radiation effects and their implications for the mechanical performance of nanocrystalline BCC metals. A fundamental understanding of competing mechanisms due to coupled defect states will foster new innovations for combating mechanical property degradation from irradiation damage, thereby providing opportunities for interface engineering through synergistic alloying-by-design methodologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this research was to elucidate the mechanisms responsible for softening in nanocrystalline body centered cubic (BCC) metals containing helium irradiation defects. The guiding hypothesis was nanoscale helium defects aggregated in grain boundaries act as stress concentrations and reduce the barrier for grain boundary mediated dislocation nucleation, which in turn manifests as mechanical softening that competes with classical irradiation hardening. Combining atomistic simulations with nanomechanical testing experiments, the influence of helium irradiation defects on the fundamental deformation processes in nanocrystalline BCC metals was explored using tungsten as a model material.  The temperature threshold for preferred grain boundary helium cavity formation was identified using helium implantation experiments performed in situ in a transmission electron microscope.  Reaction-diffusion calculations indicated that migration of the helium-vacancy complex and rapid coalescence within the grain boundaries above the temperature threshold constituted the governing mechanism for preferential trapping and large faceted cavity formation in the grain boundaries of fine-grained tungsten.  The role of pre-existing dislocation loop damage on biased helium cavity formation was studied using dual ion irradiation experiments.  Findings revealed that pre-existing loops from krypton ion irradiation were annihilated during early stages of helium implantation and followed by the nucleation of new loops that subsequently grew in size, which in a fine-grained material, would occur preferentially at grain boundaries above the previously identified threshold temperature.  Employing two grades of ultrafine-grained tungsten, softening due to helium cavities at grain boundaries was quantified through nanoindentation and attributed to cavity coalescence and an accompanying shift to grain boundary plasticity.  Complementary atomistic simulations revealed the underlying mechanisms involved stress concentrations promoting strain localization in the grain boundaries through local atomic shuffling and sliding, dislocation emission, and even the nucleation of unstable twinning events.  Research activities were integrated into new educational initiatives that advance the engagement of underrepresented students in minority participation programs, provide curriculum enrichment for engineering majors, and have facilitated the establishment of a new undergraduate materials science and engineering major at Stony Brook University. 


Last Modified: 03/27/2023
Modified by: Jason Trelewicz

Image
  • Mechanical softening from helium cavities at grain boundaries in body centered cubic metals transpires through cavity coalescence and an accompanying shift to grain boundary plasticity due to cavity induced stress concentrations promoting plastic strain localization in the grain boundaries.
    W. Streit Cunningham, Yang Zhang, Jason R. Trelewicz
    Copyrighted
    Jason Trelewicz
    Grain Boundary Softening from Stress Assisted Helium Cavity Coalescence in Ultrafine-Grained Body Centered Cubic Metals
por.por_txt_cntn:
The primary goal of this research was to elucidate the mechanisms responsible for softening in nanocrystalline body centered cubic (BCC) metals containing helium irradiation defects. The guiding hypothesis was nanoscale helium defects aggregated in grain boundaries act as stress concentrations and reduce the barrier for grain boundary mediated dislocation nucleation, which in turn manifests as mechanical softening that competes with classical irradiation hardening. Combining atomistic simulations with nanomechanical testing experiments, the influence of helium irradiation defects on the fundamental deformation processes in nanocrystalline BCC metals was explored using tungsten as a model material.  The temperature threshold for preferred grain boundary helium cavity formation was identified using helium implantation experiments performed in situ in a transmission electron microscope.  Reaction-diffusion calculations indicated that migration of the helium-vacancy complex and rapid coalescence within the grain boundaries above the temperature threshold constituted the governing mechanism for preferential trapping and large faceted cavity formation in the grain boundaries of fine-grained tungsten.  The role of pre-existing dislocation loop damage on biased helium cavity formation was studied using dual ion irradiation experiments.  Findings revealed that pre-existing loops from krypton ion irradiation were annihilated during early stages of helium implantation and followed by the nucleation of new loops that subsequently grew in size, which in a fine-grained material, would occur preferentially at grain boundaries above the previously identified threshold temperature.  Employing two grades of ultrafine-grained tungsten, softening due to helium cavities at grain boundaries was quantified through nanoindentation and attributed to cavity coalescence and an accompanying shift to grain boundary plasticity.  Complementary atomistic simulations revealed the underlying mechanisms involved stress concentrations promoting strain localization in the grain boundaries through local atomic shuffling and sliding, dislocation emission, and even the nucleation of unstable twinning events.  Research activities were integrated into new educational initiatives that advance the engagement of underrepresented students in minority participation programs, provide curriculum enrichment for engineering majors, and have facilitated the establishment of a new undergraduate materials science and engineering major at Stony Brook University.
